body: Thank you @Wenpei
Testing started [here](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/44/).

This feature is a very useful addition and the pull request already looks very nice. Just a couple of cleanups required:

1) Rewrite: By adding VAR to LOOKUP_VALID_ROW_COL_AGGREGATE, it looks as if the general case rewrites for row/col aggregate do also apply, which is, however, not always the case. The reason why it works is the correct ordering of your new rewrites. However, you still want to use the case for rowVars -> var if we have just a single row. I would recommend to either (a) add an additional constraint to the general case rewrites, or (b) remove VAR from LOOKUP_VALID_ROW_COL_AGGREGATE and add the second general case to the specific VAR rewrites.
2) Tests: It would be great if we could increase the coverage of these new testcases. First, please use a dense sparsity of 1.0>x>0.4 instead of 1.0 in order to include 0s for dense as well. Second, please make both dimensions larger than 1000 (our default blocksize) in order to test aggregation in the distributed case (your column var test already has that but we should do the same for row var too). Third, since variance requires special handling of 0s, it would be good to include empty input matrices as well.
3) Runtime: There are a couple of places where you explicitly initialize newly created arrays with 0. This is unnecessary because the Java specification guarantees that int/double arrays are 0-initialized. 
4) Comments (nice-to-have): It's nice that you added comments about the correction layout - you just might want to extend that (in one place) by (a) some note why var is included as actual value, and (b) why these values are sufficient (as all other intermediates can be reconstructed from these values)
5) Commit messages (nice-to-have): As mentioned before, the key 'SYSTEMML' is just too long for commit messages - we might want to use the old SYSML for our commits. Similarly, I would leave away these compiler/optimizer/parser/runtime tags as they do not really provide any additional information.

Thank you @gweidner

For verification, I ran the test suite again with latest master rebased with these updates on a test branch [here](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/43/). All tests (4,332) completed successfully. For comparison, I also ran test suite with the latest master [here](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/45/). All tests (4,328) completed successfully.

I really like the simplified pom.xml for the maven-failsafe-plugin's includes and excludes.

LGTM.
@shirisht Is this PR ready to merge?

I made the requested updates. I also removed the screen captures since they had internal hostnames in them. They are also very hard to keep up-to-date over time, so it's probably a lot easier to maintain the document by removing them.
Updated, rendered doc can be reviewed here: http://deroneriksson.github.io/incubator-systemml/hadoop-batch-mode.html

Yes, it looks good. 

@deroneriksson Please merge this PR.

@asurve Also, please note that parfor optimizer uses recompilation framework to generate the execution plan. Please follow the code path to see how properties from Hop are propagated to runtime instructions.
Thank you @nishi-t
LGTM.  Ideally, we also need a Spark Batch Guide as well.
Agreed regarding the Spark Batch Guide. Thank you for reviewing.

Thanks @mboehm7 for the great feedback.
1. I've incorporated the logic of the new rewrites into the existing general case rewrites with a specific constraint for each, and removed the new rewrites.
2. I've updated the dense sparsity to be 0.7, increased the dimensions to 1234 x 1432, and added tests for empty cases.  Since standard deviation relies on variance operators internally, I've tried to keep the standard deviation tests simpler to avoid growing our testing time unnecessarily.
3. I've removed those initializations.  However, I still see several zero-based initializations of the output `c` matrix in `LibMatrixAgg.java`, such as on [line 1960](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/runtime/matrix/data/LibMatrixAgg.java#L1960).  Is there a reason for those cases?
4. I have added additional comments to `getCorrectionLocation(...)` in `PartialAggregate.java`, as seen [here](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/32/files#diff-18451b8f1f6069ae271d031fe6cbc008R219).
5. I have removed the compiler, optimizer, runtime, and parser tags from the title.  While "SYSTEMML-###" is a bit long, I am concerned that changing this to "SYSML-###" could cause confusion.  For example, if someone wanted to look up the associated JIRA, searching for "SYSML-###" in a search engine would not pull up the JIRA issue, while "SYSTEMML-###" would.

**NOTE**:  This cleanup is still a work in progress.  Extending the test cases to have both dimensions > 1000, thus triggering the parallel threaded execution, exposes fairly consistent, yet somewhat random, failures, mostly in the CP cases.  The variances are somewhat close, but different enough to definitely cause concern.  The incremental aggregation uses the existing logic in `CM.java` for the aggregation.  The symptoms point towards possible numerical stability issues, off-by-one issues, or some other type of bug.  I will continue looking into it.

thanks for the cleanups. 
ad 3: Yes, this is something we still need to cleanup - feel free make the change. 
ad 5: OK, let's go consistently with the full SYSTEMML for now, once it becomes too annoying and we all agree on a prefix, we can revisit this.
ad note: Yes, we need to follow up on this one. Does it only happen for column aggregates? If yes, we would need to look at the final aggregation. Does it only happen for variance? One thing to keep in mind is that the epsilon in our tests is used as an absolute not relative tolerance - this implies that we expect larger errors for variance than for standard deviation because the former operates on squared values (and your generated data has a large enough domain). I would be fine to reduce the eps of the variance test to something like eps = Math.pow(10, -7).

@mboehm7 The failures were occurring with row, column, and full variance aggregates (and by extension also standard deviation), only in CP mode, and only for cases in which the dimensions prompted a local multi-threaded execution.  I figured out the problem -- thread contention involving the `_buff2` object in the `CM` function object during threaded variance calculations, located at [line 177](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/32/files#diff-d9237face00cb50c86d8ebb855c20000L177).  Since our unary aggregate framework uses the same function object for each thread, the `_buff2` object was getting updated by multiple threads.  This `_buff2` is used as a buffer to calculate the updated `m2` values without updating the original `m2` object -- it appears to be useful for the other moment calculations, but extraneous for the variance calculation.  Thus, I have removed it, and changed it to update the `m2` object directly.  Was there an additional design decision behind this?  If not, I'd like to also clean it up at [line 285](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/32/files#diff-d9237face00cb50c86d8ebb855c20000L285).

The row/column/full variance and standard deviation tests are passing locally now.  I'll start some full tests soon.

That's a great catch. I don't think there was a particular reason for this buffer use; variance was introduced after the moments and just reused the same infrastructure. Yes, please cleanup the variance computation in CM.

However, note that in general, we tackle this problem of shared state by not reusing function objects with internal state (e.g., see CM.getCMFnObject() compared to KahanPlus.getKahanPlusFnObject()). This is the reason why CM worked fine for multi-threaded groupedAggregate in LibMatrixAgg.
Okay great, I'll cleanup the rest of the variance code as well.  I'll be out of town for a few days, so I'll finish this up first thing on Monday.
Good catch @gweidner. LGTM.
Testing started [here](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/47/).
@mboehm7 The rest of the variance code in `CM.java` has been cleaned up.  I'm running a final full test suite, and pending any other comments, I can merge this in.
Merged.  Thanks, @gweidner!

This is great!  Can we get this into the 0.9 release?  It would be good for our first Apache release to have decently organized documentation.

cc @lresende, @mboehm7
Testing of rebased version started [here](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/48/).
@mboehm7, @niketanpansare Do you have any thoughts on updating the Spark version to 1.4.1, with particular emphasis on the change from 1.3.1 -> 1.4.1 for Spark SQL?
LGTM - thanks Mike.

From my perspective it's fine to switch to 1.4 since we ran all our experiments with 1.4/1.5 in the last five months. I would recommend to be a little bit lazy here and stick to 1.4 for now in order to prevent exploiting new features too eagerly which would loose backwards compatibility.

@mboehm7 Agreed, thanks for the thoughts!

@oza Pending the results of the tests, I will merge this in.  Thanks!

@dusenberrymw  I am fine with upgrading Spark version. Once upgraded, there are few checks in api package which are no longer necessary (for example: https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/api/MLContext.java#L1104). I can take care of it once this pull request is merged. Thanks :)
@niketanpansare Great!
@dusenberrymw I'd be happy if it made the 0.9 release. Improvement over the previous layout which was basically a list of files.

@deroneriksson Definitely.  Also, I have a few thoughts:
1. Can you rename `MLContext` to `Spark MLContext`?
2. Can you change the order from `Hadoop Batch, Spark Batch, Spark MLContext` to `Spark Batch, Spark MLContext, Hadoop Batch`?
3.  Can you rename `DML and PyDML Programming Guide` to `DML and PyDML Beginner Programming Guide`?

@dusenberrymw 
WRT
1. MLContext is also an API from Java so perhaps the existing generic name covers more ground, although the Spark Shell seems like the natural way to use the MLContext.
2. Emphasizing Spark is nice given the direction of the project.
3. Renaming programming guide is a good idea. I think Shirish and I came to a similar conclusion since that existing doc features language details for beginners, whereas a Programming Guide should probably deal with things such as parallelizing algorithms and things like that.

@deroneriksson 
1.  I  thought `MLContext` was an API for running SystemML on Spark that can be accessed via Scala or Java.  Is it possible to use `MLContext` via Java without Spark?

@dusenberrymw 
You are correct. My mistake. I was thinking of "Spark Shell MLContext" rather than "Spark MLContext".

@deroneriksson No problem!  Also, I think it would be good to get the word `Scala` on the page as well.  Perhaps we can make the following changes as well?  Would likely help with SEO.
4. `Spark MLContext is a programmatic API to SystemML.` -> `Spark MLContext is a programmatic API to running SystemML from Spark via Scala or Java.`
5. `See the MLContext Programming Guide for Spark Shell ...` -> `See the MLContext Programming Guide for Spark Shell (Scala) ...`
6. Perhaps change `Spark Shell` to `Spark Shell (Scala)` within the MLContext programming guide itself.

Again, this restructure of the documentation is great!

We seem to have had a major test suite regression (>1000 test failures) since the last positive tests, and it is affecting various builds (different branches, i.e. from different pull requests).  The common theme seems to be that the failures are only occurring with those builds that are based on the current master.  Currently investigating.

Build [47](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/47/) (for this PR), and [48](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/48/) (for PR #29) both failed.

Build [50](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/50/) is being run against the current master, and [51](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/51/) is a rebuild of the last positive build. 

We'll need to pause the 0.9 release until this is fixed.

cc @mboehm7, @gweidner, @akchinSTC, @deroneriksson, @lresende

I ran our testsuite last night successfully in my local dev environment. Could it be that there is one of the following issues (1) no clean separation of concurrent runs of our testsuite, or (2) hardware disk issues?
(1) is a good possibility, and we checked on (2) and that doesn't seem to be the case.  Did you run the suite successfully using `mvn clean verify`?
no I run the testsuite directly with junit from eclipse
Actually, I read (1) wrong.  No, the Jenkins test builds are placed in separate base directories, so they shouldn't interfere with each other.

Okay, yeah the `mvn clean verify` runs parts of the test suite in parallel, versus the synchronous testing in Eclipse (as far as I know for the Eclipse behavior).  Jenkins uses the former approach.  I don't see any issues while running the specific tests individually in an IDE.

I've attached mvn shell prompt console results when I ran the full suite on my local Windows environment which included the change made to pom.xml (PR #30).
[mvn_4282_pom_success_2h_50m.txt](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/files/86645/mvn_4282_pom_success_2h_50m.txt)

@dusenberrymw could you please try to revert commit 96019cf5e2d62410a631f754c7654e27de842bf and rerun the tests? Furthermore, there was some side effect between tests, hiding an issue - I will fix the test functions.aggregate.ColSumTest.
ok, meanwhile these issues seem to be resolved - I'll deliver the fix tomorrow morning together with same other fixes.

@mboehm7 Great!  I've started build [52](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/52/) against the current master (with the hotfix), and build [53](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/53/) is this PR branch rebased over the current master.

As a follow-up for the previous two builds, build 50 (previous current master) failed, and build 51 (rebuild of last positive build) passed.

@dusenberrymw
Made requested updates.
Also renamed MLContext Programming Guide to include Spark in the title.
Also added analytics to documentation site.

Updates can be reviewed [here](http://deroneriksson.github.io/incubator-systemml/).
Fantastic.  This LGTM.  Thanks @deroneriksson!
Rerunning the test build [here](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/54/).
Test build 54 passed.  I'll merge this in now.
Merged.  Thanks @oza for the contribution, and look forward to future ones!
Great, test builds 52 & 53 have passed.  I'll merge this in now.
@deroneriksson Can you launch a test build of this for me?
@dusenberrymw Sure, will do.
Build started [here](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/57/)
Thanks!
LGTM

Quick Start Guide updates can be seen [here](http://deroneriksson.github.io/incubator-systemml/quick-start-guide.html).
Hadoop Batch Mode updates can be seen [here](http://deroneriksson.github.io/incubator-systemml/hadoop-batch-mode.html).
cc @deroneriksson
Test build passed.
Merged.
This looks good to me for now, although we really should replace the `runStandaloneSystemML` scripts with the new `bin/systemml` script soon.  That will require updating the distribution scripts.

@dusenberrymw Good work!

Just have a couple formatting suggestions.

Was wondering about the alignment of the header content all the way to the left and the page text moved towards the left. Previously header area was centered, like [here](http://apache.github.io/incubator-systemml/index.html), which more closely matched main site [here](http://systemml.apache.org/). And the main text region was previously closer to the text alignment on the main site. Could the header area left edge be set to match the main site header left edge, and the left edge of text region be moved to match the main site text region left edge so that it has a more centered feel like the main site?

Also, perhaps for the subjects (that previously had the `  ` to handle the left margin) in the Documentation dropdown menu, we could add a class to them with a margin-left of 5px or 10px or something to move it away from the left edge a little bit?

Otherwise awesome.
Haha, yeah I just changed the header alignment right as you were commenting.  I've added some left margin to the dropdown subjects as well.
The main website needs to be fixed in a similar manner to this change as well, as it is also a bit broken on tablets and mobile devices.

@dusenberrymw
I agree about the runStandaloneSystemML vs. bin/systemml being an issue. Let's bring up the issue on the dev mailing list. I think the systemml/systemml.bat scripts might also need some minor updating/testing. Right now `systemml` is using `SYSTEM_ML_JAR=\"${BUILD_DIR}/classes\"` so you need to do a 'mvn package' for it to work. However, there is also a `#SYSTEM_ML_JAR=$( find $PROJECT_ROOT_DIR/target/system-ml-*-SNAPSHOT.jar )` line commented out, so it looks like it's ready to use a jar too. Maybe it can be set up to do both?

great thanks for the changes - just a quick general comment on the overview of "Running SystemML": it currently mixes up a couple of orthogonal dimensions: We support four different apis: command line, mlcontext, jmlc, spark ml. Standalone is just a packaging. Spark, hadoop, and singlenode are execution types - for example you can run the standalone package in hadoop execution mode. Down the road (not necessarily for the 0.9 release), we should clean this up.

@dusenberrymw
Alignment looks good. Thank you.

Yeah we should probably just switch it to always use a JAR.  That way it is ready to go for both custom-built scenarios, and official binary releases.

cc @ckadner
Good thoughts, @mboehm7.  Perhaps after our official release, we can roll that and any user feedback/confusion into one nice update.
@deroneriksson Great, I'll merge this then.

@dusenberrymw @mboehm7 
It would be great to have a good discussion regarding "Running SystemML" after this release.
Updates can be viewed [here](http://deroneriksson.github.io/incubator-systemml/dml-language-reference.html).
LGTM w/ a nice to have cleanup: instead of "in which case X is a regular matrix", we could be more specific "in which case X is a regular (n x m) matrix"
@mboehm7 Updated doc with "(n x m)".
great thanks.
LGTM.
I'll merge

@dusenberrymw could you please elaborate a little bit on the reasoning behind this change - any additional indirection via additional files and variables might create potential issues. Why is it not sufficient to have this config in the header of standalone.sh?

The additional `conf/systemml-env.sh.template` is just a convenience should a user continuously want to add more configuration, and only lives as a template until a user chooses to make use of it.  We need to consolidate all user-editable configuration to a single location, such as the `conf/` directory, and keep the rest of the code clean.

For example, this change came about because I wanted to add a remote dubugging Java option while running standalone scripts with `bin/systemml`, and it was annoying to have to change the `bin/systemml` script itself, which is a Git-tracked file, just for my local configuration.

Hi @dusenberrymw @mboehm7
I like the idea of this. Configuration data is being abstracted to conf and there is clean separation from the execution in bin so scripts don't require modification. It follows the Spark project layout pattern, where conf contains things such as spark-env.sh.template, spark-defaults.conf.template, etc. So, someone coming from Spark to SystemML would be familiar with this pattern which is nice.

@dusenberrymw @mboehm7 
Do you happen to know if bin/systemml.bat could be adapted to handle this update in a clean fashion?
cc @ckadner Any thoughts?

Ok, I got your point. However, there is one major difference - for spark, these configuration affect the actual cluster execution, while for us it only affects standalone and users might get the wrong impression that they need this, which is not the case. For example, with hadoop, you have to set hadoop_client_opts and with spark, you set the driver memory budget. 

Anyway, please go ahead for now. However, after the release we should setup some tasks to cleanup all unnecessary scripts and configurations. I really like to keep our simple deployment model: take a SystemML.jar (with packed jars for standalone) and run it wherever you like from command line without need for anything else.
Great, it would definitely be nice to have the end-user execution made as simple as possible.
great - thanks guys; then we're all in agreement.
Sounds like @mboehm7 approves for now. LGTM too. Maybe we should create a JIRA for bin/systemml.bat for consistency.
FYI, I opened [SYSTEMML-470](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-470) to track the usability improvements regarding execution modes/types.

The original*.jar has confused me when looking at the target directory following a build, so removing it is a good idea.

Eyeballing runStandaloneSystemML.sh, this 'should' be good since:

```
CLASSPATH=""
for f in ${CURRENT_PATH}/lib/*.jar; do
  CLASSPATH=${CLASSPATH}:$f;
done
```

Did you try it out with runStandaloneSystemML.sh and bin/systemml?
Oops, nevermind bin/systemml since it's using target/classes.

I didn't run it with `runStandaloneSystemML.sh`, but that script just relies on having a `SystemML.jar` file in the same directory, which is generated with the standalone distribution build from the `system-ml-0.9.0-SNAPSHOT.jar` file.  The `original*.jar` file is just a by-product of shading the JAR to include ANTLR stuff.
Sanity check: `runStandaloneSystemML.sh` does indeed still work.
Thank you for checking runStandaloneSystemML.sh. Then LGTM.
Eyeballing it, LGTM.
Rendered in GitHub markdown [here](https://gist.github.com/deroneriksson/b4db8c8358b008862751).

"SystemML will build on Linux, MacOS, or Windows, and requires Maven 3 and Java 7 (or higher)." -> "SystemML will build on Linux, OS X, or Windows, and requires Maven 3 and Java 7 (or higher; we prefer Java 8 for improved performance with multi-threaded reads)."

@deroneriksson Awesome changes.  I read through the whole page again, and added some additional changes that we might as well make at the same time.

Otherwise, LGTM.

@dusenberrymw Thank you for reviewing. I made the requested changes. I did not mention Python at this stage since I haven't run SystemML.py before. Its status might be a good question for the dev mailing list. I'll go ahead and merge.
Tests started [here](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/58/).
Tests started [here](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/59/) with additional files.
